channel.title: Google c++ style guide
channel.description:
hi.
i found this on another programming forum. i think somewhat experienced c/++ coders should read this. this helped me develop and keep a style/rule of coding that i go by now - kinda like java conventions for java programmers.
i've implemented it in my string class: http://www.moparisthebest.com/smf/index.php/topic,500784.0.html
it gives tips on what and what not to use, also gives tips on how you should indent your code.
here is the link: http://google-styleguide.googlecode.com/svn/trunk/cppguide.xml
has anyone already seen this? what do you think about it?

item.title: Google c++ style guide
item.dc:creator: @The_Enforcer The Enforcer
item.description:
@The_Enforcer wrote:

C++ naming conventions. The convention used by the standard C++ library is generally only used in third party libraries if they extend the standard library (Boost). Most other libraries out there use camelCase, while Microsoft uses PascalCase with an exception of the Concurrency Runtime which can be considered an extension to the STL since it provides you concurrent versions of STL algorithms and containers.

Read full topic

item.title: Google c++ style guide
item.dc:creator: @_s11 s1gma
item.description:
@_s11 wrote:

boost/standard c++ conventions are best

Read full topic

item.title: Google c++ style guide
item.dc:creator: @Ghost_in_stack Ghost in stack
item.description:
@Ghost_in_stack wrote:

[quote=“iKilem, post:5, topic:404126”][quote author=Ghost in stack link=topic=501181.msg3677863#msg3677863 date=1311352575]
To be honest, I was appalled that Google prescribes no exceptions and no non-const references :eek:,exceptions and non-const-references are two of the most liberating features of C++. They allow a mode of thinking that is simply impossible in their absence.
[/quote]
Didn’t read the guide, but I’m guessing it was saying you should specify reference arguments as const whenever possible, because it ensures the user that the object won’t be modified and also allows rvalues to be passed.[/quote]
And the argument they give for avoiding non-const references…
"References can be confusing, as they have value syntax but pointer semantics. "
…is highly subjective. To whom is it confusing?

I would prefer that Google reconsidered.

Read full topic

item.title: Google c++ style guide
item.dc:creator: @iKilem iKilem
item.description:
@iKilem wrote:

Ghost in stack:

To be honest, I was appalled that Google prescribes no exceptions and no non-const references :eek:,exceptions and non-const-references are two of the most liberating features of C++. They allow a mode of thinking that is simply impossible in their absence.

Didn’t read the guide, but I’m guessing it was saying you should specify reference arguments as const whenever possible, because it ensures the user that the object won’t be modified and also allows rvalues to be passed.

Read full topic
